reviews.review_title: Heavy-handed at times, but story and characters endure.
reviews.content: A classic film for a reason. Plot and characterisation leaves nothing to be desired. Only critique is that some of the dialogue, character development and moral signalling noticeably lacks nuance - especially towards the end. More could have been shown rather than told.

reviews.review_title: The Best Movie of All Time
reviews.content: "The Treasure of the Sierra Madre" is a great film!  Humphrey Bogart's finest performances were in "The Caine Muntiny" and this movie.  Walter Huston, Tim Holt, and Bruce Bennett were excellent.  As previous reviewers have mentioned, there is no excess of violence, nor is there the sex and gratuitous vulgarity commonplace in today's movies.  Instead, a good story, a fine script, superb direction, and outstanding acting make this a classic. Max Steiner' score, as usual, is superb. I can only repeat what has been said before, why can't Hollywood turn out this caliber of movie today?  For the most part what is celebrated today as outstanding, would not even be considered a "B"picture fifty years ago.  "The Treasure of the Sierra Madre" is number ONE on my list!

reviews.review_title: Treasure curse
reviews.content: Characters very well defined, image quality surprising for the time.I see this movie to be about the curse of Treasures, usually something bad happens to you or you waste your time and energy to get nothing.

reviews.review_title: "You know, the worst ain't so bad when it finally happens.." (may be some spoilers)
reviews.content: Many things are for certain to any cinephile who knows the basics of what good entertainment is: 1) Walter Huston can't be beat; an actor of the finest form who understands dramatics better than most any who came before or after him. 2) Humphrey Bogart has a certain charm on film that is unmatched. There are just so many things about the man that ooze a particular essence, and it's no wonder the man had a great career. 3) John Huston will always be remembered as one of the best filmmakers there ever was. His grandiose stories were full of human qualities, full of great dialogue and wonderful sceneries captured perfectly by the director.The Treasure of the Sierra Madre is one of those movies that tells a tale of a most important theme in history: greed. One of the reasons this film gets a 10 out of 10 for me is because it is endures; I only recently saw this for the first time after having heard Paul Thomas Anderson talk of it a bunch, and boy have I been sleeping. I had already fell in love with Bogart's acting previously via In a Lonely Place, and started my way on watching through his other performances. Here, Bogart plays the dirtiest dirt bag I've ever seen on film: the poor American starting off with most honourable intentions devolves into a paranoid, revolting, seething maniac bent on doing anyone in if they even so much as look at him with a queer eye. Admittedly, I have never seen Tim Holt in anything, but I loved his portrayal of Curtin; the almost baby faced hopeful prospector comes out to be the more honourable of the two between he and Bogart's Dobbs. However, the picture stealing role in this film goes to Walter Huston (father of the director John Huston) who absolutely tears through his character of Howard: an old seasoned prospector who takes Curtin and Dobbs up to mine for gold, and shows them how to get along while prospecting while providing some hearty laughs for the audience. There are a few times I found myself laughing just as much as Howard himself, which I don't often do aloud by myself while watching films (even comedies); later on, this compliments the film itself, as laughter is a cathartic action for Curtin and Howard in the end. From the cinematography to the writing to the acting and overall direction of The Treasure of the Sierra Madre, everything lines up perfect. An epic (I hate the overuse today of that word, but here it is truly deserved in the classical sense) tale of greed, honour, and pure evil, which could be placed today in the current state of the oil business; Paul Thomas Anderson's There Will Be Blood bridges this film to the audiences of today who are more akin to the oil industry than that of gold. Once again, that is a reason why this film holds up today because the themes here are the same ones running through the veins of society these days. In the end, two of the characters learn a highly valuable lesson that there are worse things than the loss of wealth. 10 out of 10 and HIGHLY recommended for any true lover of cinema."We've wounded this mountain. It's our duty to close her wounds."

reviews.review_title: Bogart's best
reviews.content: Bogart's career has been overrated from its very beginnings, promoting him into an acclaimed actor much faster than he deserved with some serious role on the silver screen. Such a role finally came with John Huston's The treasure of Sierra Madre", a rough script about the effects of the golden rush" on three typical American thugs. True grit as it is, the story drew the best from the actors, resulting in some memorable scenes and everlasting messages at the very end. The treasure of Sierra Madre" is a serious movie and the most serious role of Bogart's career.

reviews.review_title: A True Classic
reviews.content: This movie produces two incredible performances. While the script and director deserve a lot of credit, the performances of Humphrey Bogart and Walter Huston are what make this a truly great film.Bogart gives what is arguably the best performance of his career. He and a friend decide to go gold prospecting. They team up with veteran miner, Walter Huston, and head off into the Sierra Madre mountains. After striking it rich, Bogie's greed and paranoia lead him to suspect his partners and plot to steal their gold. His performance is memorable as a greed-fueled descent into insanity. He is paranoid, but at the same time is trying to convince himself they are conspiring against him in order to justify taking their gold.Huston is at his best in this role. As I watched it for the first time, I was amazed at how natural his performance seemed. His portrayal of the grizzled, half-crazy old coot defines how I visualize a miner to this day. In the movie, he acts as a pillar of strength and knowledge,as well as providing a buffer zone between Holt and Bogart. Whenever Holt and Bogie get into an argument, Huston steps in to keep the peace. When he is removed, the two are at each others throats by nightfall. In the end, Huston comes riding in with the cavalry, but is too late to recover the gold. But it seems to barely affect him. In fact, he seems amused. Watching that scene, I get the feeling he didn't care about getting rich, but loved the thrill of making one last big find.

reviews.review_title: One of Bogie's best films!
reviews.content: In every sense of the term, this is a classic movie. The film hasn't aged a day, and is still just as entertaining as when it was first out I'm sure. Rightfully this film was included in AFI's 100 best movies of the past 100 years. Because of the strong and believable performances of it's three stars (Bogie, Tim Holt, and Walter Huston) it has topped the list of Bogie's best films, running a close race with The Maltese Falcon. If you're a Bogart fan, definitely check this one out, you won't be disappointed.

reviews.review_title: does it really matter who you are when you are in search for "wealth"?
reviews.content: The Treasure of the Sierra Madre is a story of two young pauper Americans fitting together with an old-timer to prospect for gold in a time on which scattered gangs of bandits terrorize the countryside.The two young guys want to have lots of money while the old-timer thinks it's worth the money and adventure to settle for a peaceful old age period.Before being in search for gold they think "gold" cannot really change their soul or heart but when they really find a small gold mine in the remote Sierra Madre greed and voracity sets in between them especially because of the oversuspicious, wicked, down-trodden loser named Fred C. Dobbs.The more they find gold the more mean he becomes and he starts do become suspicious of his partners he even starts to show indications of losing his mind.It's a nice plot which is superbly acted.Besides if you saw a couple of old movies you would probably notice "The Treasure of the Sierra Madre was one of the first Hollywood films to be shot almost entirely on location outside the U.S., although the night scenes were filmed back in the studio." Based on that I can say it is much easier to produce a movie like "Maltese Falcon" than to create one like Sierra Madre. But I can't help saying I would love to see a Technicolor version of the movie.When the gold is in question black and white doesn't fit in there.You have to use your imagination to presume what you see in black and white is not sand but actually gold.

reviews.review_title: A good movie, not a great one
reviews.content: Not bad not good. Basically, Prospector becomes obsessed with gold and turns against friends. The acting was good, the scenery was good, the story was okay. Nothing much to say about this one.

reviews.review_title: Disappointed
reviews.content: I was expecting a lot from this movie but I was quite disappointed

reviews.review_title: You were shown 10 stars by many reviewers and this is part of the reason why.
reviews.content: Briefly stated, Warner Brothers, and their quest in providing a history about greed and the reasons why it changes the human condition in mankind. Teaching the best heritage of mankind to our youth allows peace and contentment regardless of their choices in how to live their lives. This movie can be used to correctly provide various viewpoints that tells a universal story of hope. Thank you kindly.

reviews.review_title: The Doomed adventure
reviews.content: Humphrey Bogart at his paranoid best.He plays an American vagrant in Mexico and gets tricked into doing some labour and not getting paid along with Tim Holt.They team up with an old prospector played by Walter Huston and start mining for gold in the dangerous mountains.Bogart is instantly suspicious of the other two and demands the gold dust is split three ways instantly.He is constantly accusing the other two of plotting to steal the others share.After fending off some bandits and Huston saving a local native child.It comes down to Bogart and Holt in a tense battle of who goes to sleep first.The score is also not bad.This is not your typical Hollywood adventure from the time this is doomed, and you are not asking yourself are they going to succeed you are asking yourself why are they even doing this?

reviews.review_title: Great movie
reviews.content: This is one of the greatest movies I've ever seen. It was made back when they made good movies, with stories and plots. I can see it over and over. There's a scene in the beginning, when Howard is talking about looking for gold and how it changes men. This scene foreshadows the whole movie. The change in Dobbs (Bogart) is gradual, until he is completely insane. It's not just about looking for gold, it's about partners going out and trying to make money. Things are fine as long as you're not making any money, but when you start to get successful, that's when the problems start. This movie is a real insight into human nature. Howards explanation about why gold is valuable is actually quite true.

reviews.review_title: Human nature
reviews.content: Friendship, greed, paranoia, triumph, failure, crisis, life and death, dreams, rackets, and more

reviews.review_title: One of the BEST!!
reviews.content: Possibly up there as one of the greatest films of how greed can change the character of man. Bogey is magnificent in his descent into madness in what I think is his best performance which gives you some scale of how good he is in this movie as he has given us some special moments in movies. This movie really does have it all apart from Romance but every other genre is included you don't even realise that till you have watched the movie. You need to watch this movie for its sheer brilliance you will not be disappointed.

reviews.review_title: Don't believe the hype.
reviews.content: I can't believe this is rated at 8.5. Whatsamatter wiv everyone? Well, we know what the matter is and that is the non thinking response of received ideas, IE. 'this is black and white, this is old, there is a famous actor in it and some famous director who's also renown for something or other I've no idea what but his name is familiar and therefore it must be good, mustn't it?' Personally, I'm not interested in any famous this and that or age or whatever. I wish to be entertained. This doesn't do it. The film starts off with a little promise and you expect to be drawn into a drama full of intrigue and the human condition with a lot of philosophy and conflict. What we actually get is a 2 dimensional 'Boys Own' style clichéd drivel all fragmented plot lines going nowhere. It felt as if the script was written as they went along and hardly any of it seemed to make any sense. There was no drama, just endless amounts of bad acting where the famous actor self consciously and unprofessionally keeps looking at the camera by accident. Basically this film is written for a five year old and insults your intelligence. 2 stars for period nostalgia and the clothes. I'd pass on it if I were you.

reviews.review_title: This movie is really wonderful!
reviews.content: The most greedy side of human nature is revealed in front of these measures of money desire, even if you were confident in your conscience before. The psychological drama is great, and the three actors also gave the best performances. This movie is really wonderful!

reviews.review_title: Masterpiece
reviews.content: One of, if not the, greatest. If you don't concur, try to grow up. It's not an action movie. It has no special effects. There is no fantasy. All it has are character, plot, great acting, insight and psychological truth. Also, the kind of justice present day Mexico (as well as certain parts of the US) could probably use a bit of.

reviews.review_title: How does yellow metal ruin people or the Drama of Gold Diggers
reviews.content:
Adventure, drama. The film adaptation of the novel of the same name by the German writer Bruno Traven, which was directed by John Huston, who was not the last in Hollywood, for personal reasons (he decided to remove his father so that he received an Oscar, and in the end he received it). I have not read the original source myself, so I will evaluate the painting as an independent work. And I came across it when I was watching Humphrey Bogart's filmography, so I decided not to delay the viewing too much. As a result, I was quite satisfied. And here's my brief opinion - how gold destroys people. I honestly admit that during the viewing I looked for flaws as best I could, but I could not find a single one, so I can only focus your attention on the expressive advantages of this picture. And this concludes the much-needed introduction.So, expressive advantages:
1. Scenario - the action of the picture takes place in Mexico in the mid-twenties of the last century. Two poor Americans Dobbs and Bob lead a beggarly lifestyle and dream of getting rich. In a flophouse, they meet an old gold digger, Howard, who talks about gold mining and the dangers that it brings. After consulting, our friends take Howard's share and go in search of gold in order to solve all their problems with one clap. But will they find gold? And if so, will they be able to resist the brilliance of this yellow metal? Maybe Howard's stories about the madness of gold miners are not such tales? And what about Lady Luck? Will she be kind to our trinity? That's why I love old movies, so it's for interesting scenarios in which you'll never guess the denouement, so it happened here. The characters are interesting and memorable, the situations are vital, and the images are not too hackneyed. This is not only an adventure story about three companions, but also a strong drama with eternal questions worth thinking about. And the drama here is even more than an adventure. The minor characters, though they fade a little against the background of the main trinity, but they play an important role in the unfolding story. And if you are tired of the same type of scenarios in modern cinema, where the scenario turns are guessed almost immediately, then you will definitely like this picture!2. Entourage - the picture was shot in the city of Tampico and in the Sierra Madre mountains, where the action takes place. Mexicans speak Spanish, which gives the picture a local flavor. Of course, I'm not a big fan of Spanish motifs and music, but I heard something, and I liked that something. Thanks to this, you believe what is happening on the screen without any second thought. Moreover, it was the first Hollywood picture shot outside the United States, although they could build similar scenery (although no, going to Mexico and hiring locals for two bucks is still cheaper than paying the same Mexicans - the builders of scenery in the United States itself).3. Morality - the picture is very instructive and shows what happens when you run for gold, throwing everything in your path and even walking through other people. It's not for nothing that there is a saying in the Russian language "the greed of the fraera ruined", it was invented for a reason, and the vitality of these words has been repeatedly confirmed. You always need to remain a person, do not leave friends in trouble, listen to knowledgeable people and do not go on about your own pride and greed, and then everything should be fine with you. And a strong ending works perfectly for this very morality.A little bit about the main characters:
1. Fred C. Dobbs, played by Humphrey Bogart, is a poor American who went for gold in search of a better share for himself. During the painting, before our eyes, a good person is transformed into a real madman, obsessed with greedy gold and jealously guarding his share, simultaneously suspecting his companions of greed. For Humphrey, it was a radical change of image after the noble detectives ("The Maltese Falcon") and romantic cynics ("Casablanca"), and he perfectly reincarnated. And how he played a laughing madman tirelessly, with shifty eyes and a gun in his bosom! It's just a must see! Bravo Humphrey! Bravo!2. Bob Curtin, played by Tim Holt, is a poor American and Dobbs' companion who went with him in search of gold. A brave and honest man who does not throw words to the wind and always tries to think with his head in order to get out of any scrape alive. Also passes the gold test, but copes somewhat better than Dobbs. Tim here was no less good and convincing than Humphrey, so Bravo!3. Howard, played by Walter Huston, is an old gold digger who helps Bob and Dobbs with valuable advice and teaches them a little about life, and his knowledge of Spanish will help the heroes out more than once in the most difficult moments. In general, Howard is a kind of father-mentor here. And Walter did a great job with this role, and the actor did get his Oscar. Bravo!Perhaps the review turned out to be extremely chaotic, but that's how I see it.And although the picture was enthusiastically received by critics, but the audience did not appreciate such a bold improvisation by Humphrey Bogart, so the box office was modest, although it beat off the production budget and even brought a small profit. But later this picture was entered into the "National Register" and now it is being played on American TV, although I doubt that many modern viewers will watch it.As a result, we have a good adventure drama about the search for gold, with a good script, vivid images, excellent scenery, Mexican entourage, pleasant music, and great acting.My rating is 7 out of 10 and my recommendation for viewing!

reviews.review_title: It's an intense story of greed and human frailty.
reviews.content: It is a seemingly natural, instinctive character for Huston, so well does he play it, and one of deep goodness and wisdom, in a tough and pragmatic body. This is a brilliantly written story, brilliantly directed to recall Westerns and Greek tragedy and Shakespeare, all at once.

reviews.review_title: Versatile and intense genre mix as precious as gold
reviews.content:
"The Treasure Of The Sierra Madre" is 1948 adventure western directed by John Huston starring Humphrey Bogart and Walter Huston.
⚪
All in all, the third collaboration between Bogart and Huston mines for gold as intensively as it digs in the hearts of men, because even if it is an adventurous tale on the surface, it is furthermore a powerful examination of humans influenced by wealth and fortune, an intense journey of mistrust, paranoia and greed, defined by the excellent performances of its leading trio, eclectic writing and a packing atmosphere, and thus it becomes an ambiguous western that stands out from other titles of the genre.
⚪
#ItsAHumphreyBogartChristmas continues with yet another collaboration of the legend and iconic filmmaker John Huston. Since the film for my milestone has been nothing short of a disaster, I knew that this late-forties film would make up for the pain I have gone through the day before, and as I expected it no differently, it was indeed a cinematic remedy. Seven years after their initial team-up "The Maltese Falcon", Bogie and Huston this time left the film-noir behind and ventured into a whole different direction, but the brilliance the both are able to create doesn't suffer from that genre shift. What kind of film is this, though? Well, at first appearance, it seems to be an adventure film, but already after twenty minutes it is palpable that Huston didn't want to abide in the boundaries of just one genre and, as crazy as it sounds, experimented with other stylistic directions as well. Yes, basically it the story of three men seeking fortune and mining for gold, but it digs deeper than that and almost effortlessly becomes a genre-fluid film that fluctuates between being a western, a gangster movie and even a (psychological) thriller. How that is possible? Well, if you are John Huston and know how humans work, you can create such a crazy genre-mix easily. Unlike his directorial debut, this Huston film locates its story in the desolate and dangerous desert of Mexico, and Bogie, who I have previously only seen as a suave and clean-cut smoothie, plays the dirty, unshaved and sneaky Fred C. Dobbs, an unemployed American drifter in search of work in the South. After he attains money and befriends two other workers, the trio starts for the wasteland in order to mine for gold. However, when the three hit the mother lode and are aware of their fortune, mistrustfulness, greed and paranoia come into the play, and as you can guess, it all goes down from there. What surprises me the most about this film is Humphrey Bogart, at that time most famous as the star of "Casablanca" and "To Have And Have Not", because in this one he plays an entirely different kind of character, and it was unfamiliar to see him like that. As mentioned above, I have only seen him with suit and hat, portraying suave, clever and cool gentlemen who are two steps ahead of their enemies, and despite some minor tendencies, always end up being the good guy. In this one? Well, it was nothing short of shocking to look at him, portraying a dishevelled and anything but elegant vagrant. Furthermore, surprising was how he even gradually turned into mischievous, paranoid and insidious madman driven by contentiousness. Speaking of which, this is also one of the finest and most intriguing aspects of the entire film. Almost in the blink of an eye, the light-hearted adventure film turns into a hideous series of uncompromising mind games, as well as an insightful anthropological study, as it graphically depicts the moral deterioration of honest men tainted by greed and wealth. Seriously, it was unexpected but nevertheless magnificent to see Bogart playing the bad guy for once, but even if his performance is excellent as per usual, I couldn't help but realizing that the legendary Humphrey Bogart is unexpectedly put in shade by one of his co-stars. Walter Huston, the father of the director and acclaimed actor himself, portrays the old man Howard, the most experienced prospector, and plays him with such an incredible authenticity and charisma (and even speaks Spanish like a native). Seriously, this time around it was someone starring opposite Bogie who was the character seemingly being two steps ahead of the others, and honestly, he was the only one I have ever seen stealing Bogart the show. The "Casablanca" superstar famously said, "One Huston is bad enough, but two are murder", referring to the depth of Walter Huston's performance, and I think that says it all. Deservedly, he won the Oscar as best supporting actor afterwards. Aside from the outstanding acting power of this film, it furthermore displays an eclectic and wonderfully written script that superbly harmonizes with the actors' capabilities, as well as the setting. From uninvited guest, over problems with bandits to altercations with each other, it offers everything and never becomes boring, quite the contrary, it ups the ante every single time. As Howard correctly states, if gold is at stake, people change completely, and this film mercilessly illuminates this phenomenon in all its gritty layers. In the final act, Bogie's character must pay the price for his greed and is eventually killed by bandits (something I never thought it would see in a movie from the forties!) and the gold they have prospected for month is gone forever. Eventually, nobody wins and the only thing the two survivors have learnt from the entire trip was that there are more important things in life than fortune, such as following one's dreams and desires. The true treasure is this insight, and I think it couldn't have ended better than this. However, if there is one minor flaw about this film, it must be how the film sometimes shifts tonally and goes from intense to cheerful in the matter of minutes and vice versa. Like, two of the protagonists have played a mind game of life and death, and one has seemingly killed the other brutally, and then it cuts to the third being spoiled by indigenous people. It is a matter of consistency that bothered me there, but its criticizing at the highest stage. In the end, it is another stroke of genius by Bogart and Huston, and a proof that they can also do something else besides film noir. It almost effortlessly took an old genre and turned it into a versatile mix that is as original as it is outstanding, and it is comprehensible how it inspired many projects that have become legendary today, namely "Indiana Jones", "There Will Be Blood" and even "Breaking Bad". If it wasn't for this classic, many great films wouldn't have been as we know them today. No pun intended, but this film is indeed pure gold.

reviews.review_title: Dust in your eye you sick dog!
reviews.content: Wow. Bogart was absolutely crazed. Fantastic drama, grippin' you by the laurels and shaking you about. This masterful film --it ain't no 'movie'-- takes you to where greed could / can / will? take us all. Makes you realise how a catastrophe like 'Subprime' can happen. Experience the darkness of that which (possibly) snakes its course through that place most dare not even look. Get on your couch, sit, watch and enjoy an adventure. Listen to the hard stab of a man hell-bent on looking after himself. Plus, now at last, I know where Mel Brooks got some inspiration from for Blazing Saddles; "Badges? we don't need no stinkin' badges".

reviews.review_title: The treasure of The sierra madre
reviews.content: Now I tell you truly, no material wealth is worth the pain of a long separation. You're young enough to make three or four fortunes.-- The Treasure of the Sierra MadreThe story of humanity under the cloak of gold panning. In the end, the whole story looks more like a fable, the greed of the back, all the last empty.With the development of the plot, the nature of human nature is gradually exposed.When they have no money, they support each other; When luck to buy lottery money, ready to partnership panning, everything about brothers loyalty, sharing weal and weal; When they began to find gold, among the three began to suspect suspicion; As the gold piled up, they eventually turned their guns on each other.The ending is absurd and full of irony. The most greedy and suspicious were killed by robbers, and the sands of the other two were scattered by a strong wind.After more than half a year's hard work, I finally drew water for nothing. At the end of the two people lost gold together laughing, with laughter cover sad, the rest is helpless, self-mockery and fate.

reviews.review_title: A masterpiece.
reviews.content: A film good in so many ways, one hardly knows where to start.  When this film was made, Hollywood studios competed to see who could do the worst job of adapting good books to the screen, often ripping the vitals out of the books they adapted, removing every trace of realism and intelligence from them.  Huston made Traven's book with style and faith to the author's sense of irony beyond tragedy.   With incredible performances and that wonderful visual style that characterizes all Huston's films, Sierra Madre only falls short for me in a couple of places.  As much as I love Max Steiner's scores, I'm not sure he was the best choice for this film, and the occasional taint of Hollywood schmaltz creeps into the script, but for the most part the movie transcends its era.  A metaphor for every endeavor men (and women) undertake together, a study in the way things fall apart around the imperfect center of human souls, and a great adventure, Sierra Madre is a narrative masterpiece.

reviews.review_title: Perfect film making
reviews.content:
I continue to be intrigued by the perfection of this film. For story telling, this film is superb. Every aspect of it goes to build the characters and the plot. There are so many expertly played scenes...some of them seemingly less important. Child actor Robert Blake is great as the child begging Bogart's Dobbs to buy a lotto ticket.
The meeting between Holt's Curtin and Dobbs. The meeting between Walter Huston and Bogart. And the film continues to unfold expertly in John Huston's cinematic eye. I hadn't seen the film for many years and just rewatched it on DVD. So many of the details of the film, I'd forgotten. Everything that happens builds to Bogart's psychotic, suspicious breakdown where he is sure that all are plotting against him.
Tim Holt deserves more recognition for his contribution to the power of this film.
At the start he seems a callow personality but as the film progresses he grows in stature as man of strength and honesty. Walter Huston's saving of the young Indian child may seem like an unnecessary diversion to some but I found it fascinating and just adds to our understanding of the character's wisdom. And of course that ending has that twist of fate that seems inevitable as we watch it, but the first time I recall I was astonished. It's an ensemble film in which the actors really play their roles in synch with one another. Let me also add a word for Bruce Bennett's Cody,the interloper, the intruder for whom they felt the need to dispose of. His character was so articulate that I thought is this reasonable to expect in these circumstances? But then the dialog throughout the film is heightened at times and at others has the rich, power of how folks actually speak. I enjoy this film throughly and it gives me a lot to ponder about the circumstances of these mens' lives and the struggle to achieve a better life...certainly a more comfortable life as Bogart's character expounds. I think it's Bogart's most nuanced and complex performance...although I note in one scene at the beginning he gives this the kind of facial tick that became a part of anyone doing an imitation. All in al great acting combined with superb dialog, story telling and directing.

reviews.review_title: This is a cute movie, but it has stylistic issues.
reviews.content: I don't know what it is up with these older movies. There are interesting stories and good cinematography, but I do not get the overacting. Maybe it is meant to compensate for the lack of color in the film or maybe it is the uneasy transition from the habits acquired in silent films where you had to do all your acting with your body. I do not know about that but I know Humphrey Bogart, as one of the main characters, starts overacting the hell out of this film.And the dialogue is often written for that occasion. "Just like I thought" and "I know what your game is" (while making sudden gestures) are the kind of sentences you can hear in this film.It does not get much better in the physical department. There is a scene where a guy is eating near the fire and he is crouching in the most uncomfortable unnatural position no one would ever eat in, unless of course they were posing for a camera, for a specific shot. The movie is not all like this but a lot of it is.Other than that, the composition in the scenes is good. In fact, if this movie was a comic book, a set of paintings or drawings, it would have been a fun experience I bet. And when the actors occasionally stop overacting, it does become a fun experience, but then it goes back to cartoonish.The movie actually keeps going from normal to cheesy to normal to crazy. And the normal makes the crazy stand out even more.But if you do not mind that the movie has a fit every now and then, it is still fun.

reviews.review_title: A Classic tale of greed and corruption
reviews.content:
If ever there was story about greed and man's ability to achieve an almost divine state of corruption, then this is it. This is a tale of three friends who in a bound of friendship set out to find gold in the Mexican Mountains. This friendship soon turns to hatred as the three prospectors develop an intense paranoia of each other.One of the prospectors Fred C dobbs (played by Humphery Bogart) in the space of two hours undergoes an incredible metamorphosis, changing from a rather personable down-and-outer to a homicidal maniac willing to kill his closest friends.
This film was directed by John Huston and shot entirely on location at Jungapeo, Mexico. It cost an incredible $3 million to make, much to the despair of Jack Warner. After seeing a prelude of the film he exclaimed, they're looking for gold alright .. mine. He also did not like the fact that Bogart's character was killed off in the end, he felt it was a mistake. He was proved right as the public in 1948 did not like film, and it became a flop at the box office.The critics though love it and hailed it as a triumph for Huston and Warner pictures. Strangely enough everybody was honoured except Bogart. Perhaps seeing the hero of Casablanca and the Maltese Falcon as the degenerate, murdering psychopath was more than the academy could endure. He was not even nominated for a Oscar.

reviews.review_title: BOGART, need I say more
reviews.content: This movie, more than any other, showcased the talents of Bogart.  He was fantastic, and stole every seen of the movie.  I am convinced that nobody could have pulled this role off, like Bogart did.  It is also nice to see, a legend of his time take a role playing the bad guy.  Unfortunely today, there are very few big time actors that would be willing to play a truly bad guy, being afraid it might hurt there image.     With all that being said it was a fantastic movie.  The camera work, music, and acting (aside from Bogart) were all first class.  The plot was very interesting, showcasing greed, deception, and paranoia, all from Bogart's character.  Anyone that will question Bogarts place, as the "Greatest of all-time", just see this movie and your question will be answered.

reviews.review_title: Great movie
reviews.content: I guess all of you will know the story of this excellent movie but I want to point out one thing that is absolutely ludicrous. Humphrey Bogart, yes good old Bogey. The fact that he wasn't even nominated for an Oscar truly makes a mockery of the awards system. He is outstanding here as the legendary Dobbs as he starts out as a decent guy but descends into a greed driven lunatic. What an absolutely stupid decision by the academy but then again they have made many ridiculous decisions over the years.The movie is terrific, the performances spot on. John Huston's direction is tremendous too. 'The Treasure Of The Sierra Madre' is one of those movies that can be watched multiple times.

reviews.review_title: Only a classic when judged by the standards of its time
reviews.content: Most of the points I'd give the Treasure of Sierra Madre, I'd give it for originality. I've seen a lot of westerns and I've seen a lot of noir films, but I'd really have difficulty pointing to another film (especially from its era) with a similar premise. There's a ton of potential in the tension among three relative strangers on their own in the wilderness, brought together only by the desire for wealth.That's not the way the film plays it, though. After a pretty decent beginning spent developing the characters and their motivations, it sends its characters out into the wilderness and attempts at tension by having Humphrey Bogart act like a rabid dog his partners are too kind to put down. Counter to type for him (and he certainly gets an A for effort for all of his wide-eyed snarling) but his character becomes tedious as the film dwells on his relentless paranoia, expecting fascination from the audience.The fact that the Hustons received awards for the film is just proof that the standards and tastes of their time were not the same, and I don't think I can call the film objectively bad for that reason, but past the first 30 minutes I was not very entertained.

reviews.review_title: This movie is one of my top ten favorite's
reviews.content: no matter how many times in watching Treasure of Sierra Madre something comes up in the movie that did'nt catch my eye before.  Over the years a number of things have brought up about the making, and the comments have stayed in my memory, and others that are watching at the time get a kick out of my commits   Play it again   Ernie N. Sowell

reviews.review_title: A character study disguised as an adventure story
reviews.content: A character study disguised as an adventure story. Slow, oppressive and authentic. You can feel the dirt and the misery.Great performances from the three leads, particularly Bogart and Walter Huston, who get the more juicy characters.Well-crafted, this black and white classic would have gained if it had been filmed in widescreen format, since it does not take as much advantage of the landscapes as other westerns. Perhaps it's for the best, though, contributing to the claustrophobic sensation.Some might find this little masterpiece (comparable to The Ox-Bow Incident, perhaps) too slow, but I thought it had a tight plot and just gave the characters space to take over the show.

reviews.review_title: I don't get it...
reviews.content: Although the acting was good, the screenplay was terrible. It was so corny at times and predictable.

reviews.review_title: great movie A-one
reviews.content: My absolute favorite movie, watching Bogey slide into insanity, is priceless, to paraphrase " nobody pulls the wool over Fred C Dobbs' eye's", or of course the " we don't need no stinking badges", I use the phrase" we don't need no stinking, "whatever" often, a gem of a movie, equally rewarding, "The Caine Mutiny" watching Bogey melt down when he is grilled and starts with the "strawberries" tale, Humphrey Bogart, I generally dislike so called "Stars" but man oh man, would I like to sit down and have a beer with Bogey, also Paul Newman is a man I could shoot the breeze with, take off with the fluffy "stars" of today, Bogey and Newman, are A-one

reviews.review_title: Worth it weight in gold!
reviews.content: John Huston and Humphry Bogart collaborated many times and have created many great films together, this being one of the best of the bunch, if not the second best, right behind "Maltese Falcon". This is a superbly made adventure drama, and a highly critical piece of commentary on society, and more specifically capitalistic societies. Within the three main characters Huston and writer B. Traven show how wealth and the desire for wealth corrupt men's souls and ultimately corrupt entire societies. In their blind lust and greed for wealth (or gold in the case of the movie) the plights of others are ignored, courtesy is exchanged for shrewdness and politeness is exchanged for malice. Even foreigners who happen along and want to share in the excess of wealth are ostracized and driven off, to the point of murder if they insist on sticking around. It is obvious that the writers had an agenda, if not to just create an amazingly entertaining film then to point out the ills of a society that is preoccupied with it's pursuit of wealth and it's misguided ideas of privilege. The fact that they are in Mexico seems to be an indictment of the way wealthy nations seem to exploit smaller nations in order to become wealthy. How poor nations are poor because others make use of the resources that they have. The fact that the main characters end up the way they do in the end is a direct result of who they are and the choices they made, but it may seem that the country they stole from finally got it's revenge on one of them, and the others get away with a lesser punishment, mainly they have their 'goods' taken back by the land they took it from.Aside from the political and social commentary by the writer of the book, B. Traven and the screenplay writer, John Huston, this is a wildly entertaining film and adventure. Back in a time when adventure films rarely left the realm of War dramas, this is a refreshing film experience. Huston creates a tense atmosphere of danger throughout the film. We feel the suspense from within the group of main characters to the outside elements that would cause harm to them. As anyone who comes along is a potential threat, to their quest for gold to their very struggle to survive. Huston makes this danger feel very real. Bogart's character is the most vibrant, and probably his best acting role ever! That is saying a lot. Bogart seems to take the viewer on a journey into madness, and when it happens it is shocking. In the beginning Bogart plays a sensible enough guy, just a little down on his luck, but otherwise a normal guy. That makes the transformation he makes all the more spectacular to watch. Tim Holt's character unfortunately falls victim to the madness swelling inside the gold hungry Bogart. Holt plays the average nice fellow, nothing spectacular about his character, except how average and nice he is, even when double crossed by Bogart's character. Walter Huston plays old man Howard, and his performance is marvelous as the crusty yet lovable world weary old man. His portrayal of the experienced gold digger is entirely believable, and very authentic. I cannot imagine anyone else playing that role and succeeding the way Huston does. I can just imagine the directer John Huston reading the book and thinking to himself, "dad would be great in this part!" And he certainly is.This film is like gold, it is worth what it is, cause there are so few films on par with it. It is so difficult to find a truly outstanding film these days, so when I see films I enjoy as much as this one, it is a real treasure!

reviews.review_title: Classic Gold Hunting Film with Career Best Bogart & Huston Performances
reviews.content: The Treasure of the Sierra Madre (A-): "I know what gold does to men's souls" - One of the most fascinating stories about the "Old West" that you don't see covered by many modern films is the gold rush. The Treasure of Sierra Madre follows a couple down on their luck Americans, one played by Humphrey Bogart in a career best performance, in Mexico who team up with an old prospector played by Walter Huston to search the Sierra Madres for gold. When their exploration strikes a good find, the men start to change. Despite the setup, this isn't a fun adventure film. It's an expertly written and executed morality tale that illustrates the nature of greed; how easily it can change a man and what he's willing to do to keep it. Once they strike gold, each successive scene cranks up the stakes and tension a level with the moral situation getting dire when a stranger shows up to their camp, when bandits arrive, when local Indians approach them, and finally when they have to get the gold back to civilization. Walter Huston's old prospector in this film did more than win the Oscar for his supporting role in this film, he crafted the archetype and stamped this role forever in his image - he's that good in this.

reviews.review_title: Don't Bogart That Oscar
reviews.content: I really enjoyed this movie.  The problem I have with a lot of older movies is that they become so outdated.  This one was not.  Bogart was funny and I particularly liked his transformation into a loon.  The old prospector was very good and the Banditos were great.  I was really surprised and I highly recommend this one.

reviews.review_title: Arguably the best movie ever made
reviews.content: The Treasure of the Sierra Madre may quite possibly be the greatest movie ever made. Yes, it is that awesome.Every element is either perfect or near-perfect (only the limitations of that era would allow an element to be only "near" perfect).The black and white cinematography is gorgeous. Very crisp and clean, with excellent compositions. Its one of those elements that works so well, because you barely notice the camera-work. This is not flashy like a Scorsese movie, this is subtle and effective.Great music. Not the most memorable score ever, but way above average.The story is absolutely timeless - a grinding, unapologetic and philosophical deconstruction of the most base aspects of humanity; and not a very positive one either. Greed, desire, jealousy, vanity, paranoia are all the key words in describing the issues that the screenplay tackles. The movie also deals with some other concepts like the American work ethic, the pioneering spirit, progress, paradise lost and found, etc etc etc. And this is just the tip of the iceberg. This movie really digs deep into the human experience - raw and harsh at its core. Other movies have dealt with these themes, some effectively some with nothing but clichés. The best of them - There Will Be Blood, Network, Wall Street...are all bastard children of the granddaddy of them all - The Treasure of the Sierra Made.Acting. While Bogey is best known for Casablanca and the Marlowe detective thrillers like The Big Sleep, TTofTSM is the pinnacle of his career. That character embodies all that is great about Bogart's acting talents. The grime, the gruff, the bad attitude, the wicked looks...its all there; Bogey at his best. But.... then there is Walter Huston. This actor steals the show like few actors have ever done before. His performance is not only flawless, it almost breaks the 4th wall - its as if the filmmakers are suddenly staring you right in the face and letting loose on you. Walter Huston - his performance and his character define this film; and elevate it to the next level of absolute greatness. Kudos here must definitely go to the writing. The lines that Huston delivers are devastatingly poignant yet savage. He has some of the best dialogue ever put on film; none of it is dated, in fact it is so modern and ahead-of-the-times that is almost seems out of place for a movie in the 1940's. For a movie almost 70 years old, The Treasure of the Sierra Madre can still hold up against any of the modern classics, in fact it still trounces 99.9% of all movies released today. This film should never be forgotten or brushed aside, it should be put on a pedestal as one of the great works of art of the 20th century!

reviews.review_title: We don't need no stinking badges.
reviews.content: A century of moviemaking has produced more than its share of films that explore the corrosive effect of greed on the human soul. From Erich von Stroheim's GREED to Martin Scorsese's THE WOLF OF WALL STREET, Hollywood has always been fascinated with how avarice brings out the worst in people. Perhaps the most famous of them all is John Huston's THE TREASURE OF THE SIERRA MADRE.Following his directorial breakthrough with THE MALTESE FALCON, Huston barely had time to move forward to his next project because America declared war on Japan -and Germany- right after Pearl Harbor. He enlisted in the Signal Corps where he was responsible for making documentaries crucial to the war effort, often risking his life filming right in the midst of combat, especially at San Pietro. But not all of his work was appreciated by the Army; they heavily redacted one in which Huston documented the psychological stress suffered by soldiers, which the brass considered demoralizing.Subsequent to his release from military duties, Huston was restless, occasionally doing uncredited script doctoring until he could find his first postwar project. When he read "The Treasure Of The Sierra Madre", written by the mysterious B Traven, he knew it needed to be made! Thanks to Humphrey Bogart's interest, Huston was able to pick up where he left off at Warner Bros, but there was a bit of a problem. The character Huston intended for Bogie wasn't a good guy like Rick Blaine or Sam Spade or Philip Marlowe. Fred C Dobbs was as cynical as the others, but he was a greedy SoB without a code of honor. How would Bogie's fans react to him playing such a rat?John's father Walter Huston was happy to have helped out his son with an uncredited cameo in THE MALTESE FALCON, but in THE TREASURE OF THE SIERRA MADRE he was was given one of the greatest roles of his career . However, being at the age of 63, Huston pere just wasn't too thrilled about working on location in the mountains. Bogart was even less than enthused; born and raised in New York, the lifelong city slicker hated outdoor filming, much preferring the comfortable confines of the studio. But the material was too good for either of them to turn down.THE TREASURE OF THE SIERRA MADRE takes place in the Gulf coast town of Tampico circa 1925. Fred C Dobbs is one of many American expats down on his luck. Employment is scarce down there, and Dobbs takes to scrounging for spare charge from turistas, one of whom is played in a cameo by John Huston himself. Dobbs comes across a fellow Yank named Curtin (Tim Holt), who's also having trouble making ends meet.

reviews.review_title: Down Mexico Way
reviews.content: In the film three desperate American drifters in Mexico join forces to prospect for gold. But somewhere among the remote mountains of Durango things go terribly wrong, and they end up fighting for their lives. Finally the three men discover what is truly important.In 1941, Warner Bros bought the movie rights to the book "The Treasure of the Sierra Madre". The idea was that the studio's new, young star John Huston would direct, but then World War II broke out. The plans had to be put on hold, and it would take until 1946 before Huston could return to the film. He made it clear that he wanted his father, well-known actor Walter Huston, in one of the leading roles.That was not the end of the director's demands. Despite studio boss Jack Warner's protests, Huston insisted on shooting "The Treasure of the Sierra Madre" entirely on location in Mexico. Which was something completely unheard of at the time. Most big, A-list Hollywood productions were made at home on the studio's sound stages.Luckily John Huston's gamble paid off. Watching the movie now you can almost feel the dry, hot air burning in your lungs. Sense the gravel and dirt crunch between your teeth. Shooting on location also created a different tension in the actor's. Away from the comfortable surroundings of the studio they were pushed into giving whole new levels of tight, edgy performances.Although Jack Warner initially detested the film, it paid rich dividends for the company. In addition to being very successful at the box office, "The Treasure of the Sierra Madre" won three Oscars at the Academy Awards. One to Walter Huston for Best Supporting Actor, and two to John Huston for Best Director and Best Screenplay. Incidentally, that was the first - and so far - the only time a father-and-son team had managed that feat at the Awards.

reviews.review_title: Bogie was robbed
reviews.content: "Treasure of the Sierra Madre" has always been one of my favorite films and it is still firmly planted in my personal top 20. It is rightly renowned and respected as one of the greatest films of all time. I also feel that Bogart's failure to get an Academy Award nomination for his classic performance as Fred C. Dobbs. He might not have beaten out Lawrence Olivier's winning performance as "Hamlet," but he certainly should have been nominated. His failure to be nominated and James Cagney's failure to be nominated for his performance as Cody Jarrett in "White Heat" the following year are the two biggest omissions in Academy history.

reviews.review_title: This is a well crafted film with no weak spots in any of its departments.
reviews.content: Treasure of the Sierra Madre. At the end I was left astounded. Such a dynamic movie with lots of morals, an intelligent and well written script, alot to say about the nature of human beings when it comes down to money especially gold, and the desire and temptation that's to follow perfectly captured by the main cast. Its very well acted and masterfully directed.Surprisingly underneath its tough exterior is a human side, is it tough to stay humble under the circumstances? I would say most certainly but Walter Huston's Howard would show us otherwise. I think that's what puts it over the top. Its a unique film that's not your typical Hollywood fanfare, very original and stands out in a crowd even after 70 plus years. Bogart has a string of hits in his library (Key Largo same year!) but this is certainly one of his most memorable. He turns it up a few notches for this banger.Alot of the story deals with the lure of gold and riches but its so much more. Its deep and fascinating. When gold becomes more valuable than water than something's really gone wrong and this movie will teach you all about it. A winner in everyway! Very deserving of all its oscars!

reviews.review_title: A Classic That Is Truly Great
reviews.content: Walter Huston, Tim Holt and Humphrey Bogart star in this ideal film about two down-and-out Americans who team up with an old prospector to find gold in the wilds of Mexico. Throw in a cameo by acclaimed director John Huston, and what more can you ask for? Walter Huston turns in one of the best acting performances I've ever seen as the savvy old prospector who gives it one more try. Dreams of gold dazzle the imaginations of the characters played by Holt and Bogart; but as the wealth starts to build up amid the physical hardship, greed laboriously works its way into their hearts like a gila monster clambering into camp. Will The Lord play tricks on those who choose to follow the siren song of riches? Watch this movie and find out.

reviews.review_title: Were the badges made of dung?
reviews.content: I doubt the Federales made their badges out of dung. But Gold Hat the bandit, despite pretending to be the Mounted Police, refers to their badges as "Stinkin' Badges". Probably because he hates them so.It's funny quirks like this that makes John Huston and Humphrey Bogart's Treasure of the Sierra Madre so enjoyable. It's so human, something a lot of movies back then lacked. Movies lacked it even today!In this tale of greed, human nature, bandits, gold and donkeys we meet Fred C Dobbs, a workless American begging his way around the Mexican city of Tampico. After he and another beggar Curtain got swindled by an crooked scumbag they decide they decide to go panning for gold with the help of Walter Huston, an old prospector who lives in a boarding house they had spent a night once.Soon they come up against the darker side of Human Nature: GREED! Can they survive the terror and horror this five lettered word causes? Can they remain friends? Can a person like you enjoy this movie?The only answer I can give you without spoiling anything is that you must go and find out for yourself. Go watch this movie! Get up and watch it.NOW!

reviews.review_title: Simply put, a true representation of motion pictures...when done the right way.
reviews.content: This is one of the best movies. The acting, direction, story and morals are ones that will never be forgotten. If you are one of those types that thinks humanity is a perfect race then this movie is a wake-up call for you. It shows that with the desire of material possessions, there can be no communism or perfect society. Man is a greedy species that will go out of their way to gain what they treasure the most. The performances in this movie are great particularly those of Walter Houston as Howard, a man who struck it rich, but was lucky enough to have lived after the consequences of greed. Bogie and Holt are good too and Bogart shows us all that anyone can go over the edge about something. After watching this movie, you will not only have had a good 2 hours well spent, but an understanding that some things are worth more than gold and sadly, greed kills. The true treasure of this movie is in its ability to make us all realize that our world will never be perfect and that the true treasure is resisting material possessions.

reviews.review_title: HOW DO I ESTEEM THEE, LET ME COUNT THE WAYS...
reviews.content: Ambience-you're in Vera Cruz Feb 1926; superb direction by John Houston [and bit part actor, panhandled American] Barton MacLane strutting with ill-gotten lucre and Mexican strumpet. [alphonso bedoya would require 3 voluminous tomes] the music background as tim holt reads letter of wife of just deceased bruce bennet  _"the fruit trees are especially verdant this season.." robert blake as lottery kid vendor. Bogart as fred c dobbs---poor man's paranoic--Walter houston--etc etc etc etc. Our existential plight is our awareness that our loved ones are mortal, the past is irretrievable and the cosmos is pointless, but I've recapured January 1948 when it was released in USA. at least for an evanescent remembrance of a time past.

reviews.review_title: Perfection from John Huston and company...
reviews.content: In recent years I've taken to availing myself of the extensive DVD collection held by the Las Vegas Clark County County Library District and have as a result seen some excellent films, ranging from the latest blockbusters to Kurosawa and more. A recent move put me nearer a branch that's pretty depauperate in their holdings (I can still order DVDs from the main collection and have them delivered to this branch, but sometimes the week is a 'dry' one in terms of what among my requested titles is available) and most of what they do have consists of older titles and television shows. This has lately turned out to be a happy situation, though, encouraging me to look at some old films -- until recently, it'd been a long tome since I'd watched much in the way of films dating from earlier than the late-'70s -- and discovering and rediscovering some excellent work. "Red River," "The African Queen" (pretty sure I went my whole life 'til now without seeing this brilliant piece), "Some Like It Hot," "Father Goose," "The Searchers," and many others, some of which I'd perhaps seen as a kid but that now resonate far more. This film rates right at the top of those old films and, indeed, right at the top of films ranked by ANY criteria.A good thirty or so years ago (man, where does the time go?) I saw this film on TV and I loved it. Stumbling across it in the library yesterday, and having recently seen and loved "The African Queen," I decided to give it another whirl. Good move. I have to say it: John Huston, as with John Ford, Kurosawa, and others, is highly at risk of being overrated by consensus but the truth is that he can't be rated highly enough. The man was a visionary. And the actors he so expertly films are uniformly excellent. Every of the principals turns in a solid performance, nuanced and grittily realistic; this is no mean feat given the highly stylized and theatrical screen acting style that was still pretty much de rigeur even in the late '40s. The acting in this film would not be terribly out of place in a film made 50 years later. This and "The African Queen" reminded me, given that I hadn't seen one of his films in at least two decades, that Humphrey Bogart was more than just the weird-looking little dude with the characteristic voice and overbite; the man could act! The great Walter Huston, of course, steals the show with a portrayal that's both at turns comedic and deadly serious but that is utterly convincing. I like the use of Spanish dialog in the film, too. The film's components blend seamlessly to fairly ooze atmosphere. And, as with many films from the period by such luminaries as John Ford and Howard Hawks, the scenery is used to magnificent effect even within the constraints inherent to black-and-white film (a medium that also, of course, provides some dramatic advantage if used well).This is truly a film for the ages. A ripping good yarn, expertly told and flawlessly crafted. It's over 60 years old now, monochrome, and constrained by the screen censorship of the time, but it more than holds up and remains a true classic for all time. Hmmm...I may just have to see about checking out this other thing, a little film called "The Maltese Falcon," before too long...

reviews.review_title: Gold - It's all in the finding.....
reviews.content: This is the one film that never ceases to be of interest to me no matter how many times I watch it. The performances of the three main characters are outstanding. I particularly like Tim Holt as Bob Curtin. He has less to work with than Bogart whose paranoia and mental breakdown give him the chance to use all of his physical and vocal quirkiness. Walter Huston is also spectacular as the experienced older man who is wise, jovial, ebullient and serious when the moments call for it. Holt, however, plays a character who is just plain honest and without affectations. Beside Bogart and Huston, you would expect Holt to be the obvious weak link but it is Holt's character that "finds the gold" by the end of the film and Holt's performance is the unexpected gold in the film.Holt portrays strength of character in the face of temptation and provocation. Yes, Curtin thinks about leaving Dobbs in the mine cave-in but he does not. If he was above temptation, the significance of his character would be lost. Apparently, Holt asked for a temptation to do wrong scene so Curtin would not be seen as being without a potential character flaw. What I like about Curtin is that he voluntarily struggles to understand and struggles to do the right thing. In the face of Dobbs' paranoia and twisted logic, Curtin is out of his depth but will not resort to cruelty or violence. Holt's reading of the letter from Cody's wife after Cody has been killed by the bandits is one of the most poignant moments in film. I have heard some people say it was unnecessary but I feel that it is central to the main theme of the film - what is of true value in this world? Curtin's growing realisation as he reads is a tribute to Holt's ability as an actor. He evokes an awareness of his own destiny through the letter because Curtin has already revealed his plan to buy a peach orchard with his share of the gold. He wants to provide an activity for him and others to enjoy as he had done as a boy. Watch for the contrast as the self-centered Dobbs displays only a passing interest in what the letter has to say. His plans for his future wealth are for his own aggrandizement and the satisfaction of physical desires.When all seems lost at the end of the film, Curtin and old Howard weigh up exactly what has been discovered through their experience. Howard already knew it when he started out with his two inexperienced young goldseekers. It is the activity itself that Howard values. He is a prospector and he enjoys using all his skills developed over the years. He enjoys showing others what the whole experience of prospecting is all about. Howard even knows that it entails greed, mistrust and betrayal. I love the look he gives when Curtin and Dobbs shake hands on their commitment to their friendship. He knows it will be tested and fractured by gold. Why does Howard continue with the venture even though he knows where it could lead? Because it is part of the ride. There is a price to pay for prospecting with partners but he is willing to pay it for the excitement and camaraderie. In the end, Curtin has come to understand that finding fulfillment through having a purpose in life is all the gold anyone needs. Sharing that purpose with others makes it even more valuable. A simple truth but what a brilliant exposition of it by John Huston whose interpretation of the B. Traven novel produced a masterpiece.Tim Holt's career as an A grade film actor ended with his performance as Curtin. He went back to playing good guy cowboys in Saturday matinée second feature films. I hope the memory of his performance as Curtin sustained Holt because, in my opinion, every actor needs to know how good they can be at least once in a career. Tim, you were the gold in The Treasure.P.S. Watch for the look Walter Huston gives to the camera as the pretty Mexican Indian girl strokes his chin. He raises his eyebrows as he considers what he might do and then gives a slight shake of the head. No, it's not worth the effort for the wily old Howard. He knows that it is a trap for young players. It mostly doesn't live up to expectations and can lead to all sorts of problems that Howard just doesn't need.

reviews.review_title: Again, mankind is evil...
reviews.content: The Treasure of the Sierra Madre is an allegory of the human condition. A powerful glimpse into the murky waters of what motivates the heart and soul of mankind, which is greed and the selfish lust for money and survival.The story concerns three unlucky men who stumble upon the idea to mine for gold, agreeing to split their findings in an equal partnership. It brilliantly conveys the presence of darkness in the lighted garden of mankind's hope for goodness, and how man's inability to sustain it makes him impossible to be trusted. The story also reveals the possibilities of goodness that lie beneath the surface, that in some hearts, the presence of nobility is strong enough to overcome the iniquity that would normally prevail, after a period of trial and suffering has come and gone.Ultimately, The Treasure of the Sierra Madre is a glimpse across the whole timeline of the human experience, going all the way back to the Garden, when the ground was cursed for the sake of mankind, and every imagination of his heart became evil from his youth. This story is as much a treasure to behold as the treasure it tries to reveal from within, as it shines the light of truth into the corrupted cavern which is the human heart, affirming with tragic reality that despite all his efforts to the contrary, mankind is evil, and subject to the windy, dusty whims of Fate, Destiny, and God.

reviews.review_title: Seeking that shiny treasure just might get you something else
reviews.content: For The Treasure of the Sierra Madre, Humphrey Bogart and John Huston teamed up for another great classic film. This time around Bogart plays the adventurer Fred C Dobbs, who while working as a contractor in Tampico, Mexico learns from an old prospector (Walter Huston) that there is gold treasure waiting to be found up in the Sierra Madre mountains. He, his friend Bob Curtin (Tim Holt) and the old prospector set out to seek their fortune. Along the way, things really don't turn out as they expected - at all. This is a tense action thriller. It goes way beyond being just the story of some guys going up in the mountains to find some gold. In the end, maybe the mindless pursuit of shiny metal stuff isn't all it's cracked up to be.

reviews.review_title: What a letdown.
reviews.content: They say a great film stands the test of time. I totally agree with that statement and this one was just one of those films till the last 20 minutes. Such a dramatic buildup with no payoff in the end. So Dobbs gets his just due and Howard and Curtain lose the gold they worked so hard to obtain. They laugh about it when they realize they lost all their riches?? I guess Howard doesn't care since he's made to be a playboy by the Mexican people. And Curtain just accepts he's alive and he'll just strike it rich somewhere else. Guess people think this movie is great since Bogart's in it. He is one of the greatest actors ever but this film but feels like the screenwriter couldn't come up with a good ending so he just ended it. What a letdown!
